awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Optimization and Sampling in Stochastic Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program project is to develop new methods for optimizing and predicting performance of complex systems that are described by stochastic simulation models. Such systems arise in various areas such as finance, engineering design, systems biology, and manufacturing, and are often characterized by complexities, nonlinearities, and uncertainties in their dynamics. The major challenges in the optimization and prediction of the system performance are the expensive evaluation of system models, lack of structure in the performance measure, huge search space, and the need to address the balance between efficiency and accuracy. This research aims to make strides towards these challenges by developing new theory and methodologies. The proposed methods will be applied to modeling of a class of biological systems from experiment data and studying modes of behaviors of these systems, helping to reveal functional mechanisms and design principles of biological systems. This project also supports the PI's educational objective to integrate research with course development and in-classroom teaching, engage more females and underrepresented minorities in engineering, and expose high-school students and middle-school girls to the field of industrial engineering and operations research.


If successful, this research will provide a set of new algorithms that possess both superior practical performance and rigorous convergence guarantees for the following two problems: (i) simulation optimization; and (ii) characterization of the response space of a system model. For simulation optimization, an algorithmic framework will be developed by integrating the central idea of model-based methods from deterministic nonlinear optimization with classical gradient-based search in a seamless way. To efficiently explore the response space, a new approach is proposed to sample from the response space and the parameter space iteratively, which takes advantage of the simple structure of the parameter space to circumvent the nonlinearity of the model while using the information on the response space to expedite the search in the parameter space.

por.por_cntn:
A variety of systems require simulation and optimization techniques to evaluate and improve the system performance. Such systems are often characterized by complexities, nonlinearities, and uncertainties in their dynamics, and they are often described by computer simulation models. The major challenges in the simulation and optimization of those systems are the expensive evaluation of system models, lack of structure in the performance measure, huge search space, and the need to address efficiency and accuracy. During the period of this grant, the PI and her team developed new theory and methodologies for the following two essential problems: (i) simulation optimization, i.e., optimization of systems whose performance is evaluated through stochastic simulation of the system model, and (ii) exploration of the response space via sampling, i.e., exploring and characterizing system performance throughout the entire parameter space.

 

Our developed simulation optimization algorithms are efficient and effective in solving a wide variety of optimization problems that require expensive function evaluations/simulations for performance estimation. We also developed a software based on our algorithm Gradient-based Adaptive Stochastic Search (GASS), which is available to public. Our developed approach for sampling from model manifolds has addressed a new problem that cannot be well tackled by past techniques. These methodologies have been applied to experiment design and model reduction is systems biology, which has potential benefits to prognosis prediction and therapeutic target design in cancer research.

 

This grant has also provided multiple opportunities for education, training, and outreach. Our research has involved one postdoctoral fellow and six graduate students including an African American student. They were trained in how to do scientific research and participated in every aspect from conception of ideas to dissemination of final results. Research advances from this project has been incorporated into lectures and student projects in two graduate courses that the PI developed and taught. To encourage and engage more female students in research, the PI participated in the Women in Engineering (WIE) program in the College of Engineering at Georgia Tech through the following activities: (i) speaking at WIE events based on her experience and research projects, and (ii) luncheons with female engineering graduate students. In addition, the PI served as a faculty advisor in the WIE-organized summer camp of Technology, Engineering and Computing (TEC camp) for middle school girls.
